awd_titl_txt: EAR-PF:Stratigraphic paleobiology in continental settings: Developing a sequence-stratigraphic framework of fossil preservation in continental deposits through model building and
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Katharine Loughney has been awarded an NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship to investigate large-scale controls on fossil preservation at the University of Georgia under the mentorship of Dr. Steven Holland. Many factors contribute to the preservation of fossils, including the habitats in which plants and animals lived, and the geologic processes that control the burial of their remains. In marine environments, water depth is a major control on habitat, sedimentation, and animal abundance, and the rock and fossil records of marine systems can therefore be studied in relation to their mutual drivers. On land, tectonics, climate, elevation, and stream processes are important controls on the spatial distribution of habitats and the burial of organisms. The interaction of these controls is complex and has not been as extensively studied as those in the marine realm. The goal of this project is to study the preservation of fossils in relation to the controls on habitat and burial in terrestrial environments. Through modeling fossil accumulation under varying tectonic and climatic states to predict the occurrence of fossils in sedimentary basin fill, and by testing these predictions in the field, the large-scale drivers of preservation can be better constrained. The outcomes of this project will enhance understanding of how tectonics, climate, and sedimentation processes control fossil preservation and will allow the occurrence of fossil-bearing strata to be predicted. This project will involve undergraduate students in field and laboratory work, while project findings will be incorporated into field-based paleontology courses to contribute to the training and education of graduate students. Additionally, the project will be the basis for public museum displays.

Accommodation and sedimentation are the two main stratigraphic controls on the distribution of sedimentary facies, which can be evaluated using sequence stratigraphy. Stratigraphic paleobiology integrates the fossil record with sequence-stratigraphic architecture, revealing the predictable occurrence of fossiliferous facies. The goal of the proposed research is to apply the principles of sequence stratigraphy to understand the distribution of fossiliferous facies in relation to the history of accommodation and sedimentation in continental extensional-basin sequences. Extensional basins are important repositories of the continental fossil record, and their tectonic and facies evolution is predictable and well characterized. Dr. Loughney will: 1) develop a conceptual model of fossil accumulation in alluvial systems tracts that incorporates the intra- and extrabasinal controls on sedimentation in extensional continental basins, and 2) test the model with field work in the Miocene Stewart Valley Group of Nevada. Characterizing the facies relationships and stratigraphic occurrence of fossil localities through the Stewart Valley Group will test the predictions of the model and demonstrate how fossil preservation changes through the history of accommodation and sedimentation in the basin. This research will enable patterns of evolution and extinction in continental plants and animals to be integrated with stratigraphy and preservation across basins.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The fossil record offers insight into extinct ecosystems and the plants and animals that inhabited them. The preservation of fossils depends in part on two factors: the habitats where plants and animals lived, and the geological processes that contribute to the burial and preservation of their remains. These processes vary among environments, and some environments have conditions that favor the long-term preservation of fossils. Patterns in the fossil record reflect these variable conditions of preservation in addition to patterns that occur because of evolution and extinction processes. Differentiating among these processes is key to understanding the history of life on Earth.

The goals of this project are to model the preservation of fossils in nonmarine sedimentary basins. Tectonics, sedimentation, and climate are major controlling forces on the formation of basins and the environments of deposition that develop through time. The preservation of fossils is affected by changes in these controls and the associated changes in environments. This means that the types of fossils that form in sedimentary basins should change over time, reflecting the changing environments.

Across all types of basins, relative changes in tectonic subsidence, sedimentation, and water balance determine the accumulation of rock layers that form the stratigraphic record. The relationship between these three controls can be shown in a three-dimensional model space with subsidence, sedimentation, and water balance as the three axes. Notably, water depth and the thickness of sediment that can accumulate in a basin is limited by the amount of space available for water and sediment, which is controlled by subsidence. At low levels of subsidence, only thin sedimentary deposits are preserved, whereas thick sedimentary deposits can accumulate when subsidence is high. Visualizing changes in subsidence, sedimentation, and water balance of a basin in a three-dimensional space aids the evaluation of changes in stratigraphy through time. This model allows basin histories to be compared and shows that basins forming in similar tectonic settings have similar trends through time. Foreland and extensional basins show similar trends related to common tectonic histories, and major stratigraphic changes in individual basins are related to the changing relationship of subsidence, sediment, and water balance.

In basins that form as a result of tectonic extension, subsidence decreases through time, causing environments in the basin to change in a predictable way. Alluvial fans and lakes form early in the history of the basin, and floodplains form later in basin history. Given this predictable series of environments, it is possible to predict when conditions will favor the preservation of vertebrate, plant, and invertebrate fossils. Plant, invertebrate, and fish fossils are most likely to be preserved in lake sediments that form earlier in basin history, and terrestrial vertebrates are more likely to be preserved in floodplain deposits that form later in basin history. However, because rates of subsidence differ across extensional basins, patterns in fossil preservation will also differ depending on location within the basin. In the center of the basin where subsidence rates are high, lake deposits will dominate, and the preservation potential of fossils will be high; floodplain and channel deposits will be more prevalent, and preservation potential will decrease with distance from the basin center. The sedimentary and fossil records from different parts of the basin will therefore be different, which may make stratigraphic correlations difficult across extensional basins.

These model predictions can guide field investigations in the stratigraphic records of extensional basins to more accurately interpret patterns in their fossil records. Identifying controls on preservation will help paleontologists reconstruct the ecosystems of these basins and will help distinguish preservation-related patterns from evolution- and extinction-related patterns in fossil species. The outcomes of this project are being incorporated into public museum displays and will contribute to field courses that train graduate students to collect and analyze stratigraphic information.
